contentItem.text: Orangutans have an huge arm span. They can stretch their arms up to 7 feet (2 meters) from fingertip to fingertip. Orangutans are also very strong. An adult male is said to be as strong as more than 5 men!

Orangutans spend most of the day looking for food. They love fruits and leaves, but they also eat bark, insects and, on rare occasions, meat. Baby orangutans stay with their moms for 6 to 7 years before they are old enough to live on their own.
Orangutans live in small patches of Indonesia. Because they live in the trees they are threatened by logging and habitat loss.

Orangutans spend most of their time high in the trees and babies stay close to their moms for protection. Orangutans have few natural predators, but sometimes clouded leopards and tigers can prey on them, especially when they go to the ground.

Orangutans spend most of their lives in trees and travel by swinging from branch to branch with their long arms and building a new sleeping nest almost every night. Male orangutans like to live alone and make rumbling calls to warn others to stay out of their territory. The calls are so loud, they can be heard from 1.2 miles (2 kilometers) away!
